content.text: Define gravitational field strength
Calculate the radius of the orbit of the satellite
radius =   .........  m
Show that the radius of the new orbit is \(9.4 \times 10^{6} \text{m}\)
State, with a reason, whether the gravitational potential energy of the satellite increases or decreases
Determine the magnitude of the change in the gravitational potential energy of the satellite
Rockets on the satellite are fired so that the satellite enters a different circular orbit that has a period of 150 minutes. The change in the mass of the satellite may be assumed to be negligible
The Earth may be assumed to be an isolated uniform sphere with its mass of \(6.0 \times 10^{24} \text{kg}\) concentrated at its centre
A satellite of mass \(1200 \text{kg}\) is in a circular orbit about the Earth in the Earth's gravitational field. The period of the orbit is 94 minutes
Show that the number of gas molecules in the cylinder is \(1.4 \times 10^{23}\)
Use kinetic theory to explain why, when the piston is moved so that the gas expands, this causes a decrease in the temperature of the gas
The average translational kinetic energy \(E_{\mathrm{K}}\) of a molecule of an ideal gas is given by
where \(k\) is the Boltzmann constant and \(T\) is the thermodynamic temperature
Calculate the increase in internal energy \(\Delta U\) of the gas during the expansion
The work done by the gas during the expansion is \(76 \text{J}\)
Use your answer in (i) to explain whether thermal energy is transferred to or from the gas during the expansion
The gas expands so that its volume increases to \(2.4 \times 10^{-3} \text{m}^3\) at a pressure of \(2.3 \times 10^5 \text{Pa}\) and a temperature of \(288 \text{K}\), as shown in Fig. 2.2
An ideal gas is contained in a cylinder by means of a movable frictionless piston, as illustrated in Fig. 2.1
Initially, the gas has a volume of \(1.8 \times 10^{- 3} \text{m}^3\) at a pressure of \(3.3 \times 10^5 \text{Pa}\) and a temperature of \(310 \text{K}\)
State what is meant by simple harmonic motion
A trolley of mass \(m\) is held on a horizontal surface by means of two springs. One spring is attached to a fixed point P. The other spring is connected to an oscillator, as shown in Fig. 3.1
The springs, each having spring constant \(k\) of \(130 \text{N} \text{m}^{-1}\), are always extended
The oscillator is switched off. The trolley is displaced along the line of the springs and then released. The resulting oscillations of the trolley are simple harmonic
The acceleration \(a\) of the trolley is given by the expression
where \(x\) is the displacement of the trolley from its equilibrium position
The mass of the trolley is \(840\mathrm{g}\)
Calculate the frequency \(f\) of oscillation of the trolley
State the name of the effect giving rise to this maximum
At any given frequency, the amplitude of oscillation of the trolley is constant
Explain how this indicates that there are resistive forces opposing the motion of the trolley
The oscillator in **(b)** is switched on. The frequency of oscillation of the oscillator is varied, keeping its amplitude of oscillation constant
The amplitude of oscillation of the trolley is seen to vary. The amplitude is a maximum at the frequency calculated in **(b)**
Outline the use of ultrasound to obtain diagnostic information about internal body structures
State what is meant by the _amplitude modulation_ (AM) of a radio wave
the wavelength of the carrier wave
wavelength =   .........  m
the bandwidth of the modulated wave
bandwidth =   .........  kHz
the maximum frequency of the audio signal
maximum frequency =   .........  kHz
A radio wave is modulated by an audio signal
The variation with frequency \(f\) of the amplitude of the modulated wave is shown in Fig. 5.1
Determine:
The power of a radio signal at a transmitter is \(P_{\mathrm{T}}\)
At a receiver, the received power \(P_{\mathrm{R}}\) is given by the expression
where \(x\) is the distance, in metres, between the transmitter and the receiver
For the transmission of this signal, the attenuation is 73 dB
Determine the distance \(x\)
An isolated metal sphere of radius \(r\) is charged so that the electric field strength at its surface is \(E_0\)
On Fig. 6.1, sketch the variation of the electric field strength \(E\) with distance \(x\) from the centre of the sphere. Your sketch should extend from \(x = 0\) to \(x = 3r\)
The de Broglie wavelength of a particle is \(\lambda_0\) when its momentum is \(p_0\)
On Fig. 6.2, sketch the variation with momentum \(p\) of the de Broglie wavelength \(\lambda\) of the particle for values of momentum from \(\frac{p_0}{2}\) to \(p_0\)
Fig. 6.2
A radioactive isotope decays with a half-life of 15 s to form a stable product
A fresh sample of the radioactive isotope at time \(t = 0\) contains \(N_0\) nuclei and no nuclei of the stable product
On Fig. 6.3, sketch the variation with \(t\) of the number \(n\) of nuclei of the stable product for time \(t = 0\) to time \(t = 45 \text{s}\)
State what is meant by the capacitance of a parallel plate capacitor
Show that the average current \(I\) in the ammeter is given by the expression
For a potential difference \(V\) of \(150\mathrm{V}\) and a frequency \(f\) of \(60\mathrm{Hz}\), the average current in the ammeter is \(4.8\mu \mathrm{A}\)
Calculate the capacitance, in pF, of the capacitor
capacitance =   .........  pF
A capacitor of capacitance C is connected into the circuit shown in Fig. 7.1
When the two-way switch is in position A, the capacitor is charged so that the potential difference across it is \(V.\)
The switch moves to position B and the capacitor fully discharges through the sensitive ammeter
The switch moves repeatedly between A and B so that the capacitor charges and then discharges with frequency \(f.\)
A second capacitor, having the same capacitance as the capacitor in **(b)**, is connected into the circuit of Fig. 7.1. The two capacitors are connected in series
State and explain the new reading on the ammeter
new reading =   .........  A
Calculate the potential \(V^{+}\) at the non-inverting input of the op-amp
At \(10^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\), the resistance of the thermistor is \(2.5\mathrm{k}\Omega\)
State and explain whether the light-emitting diode (LED) is emitting light
Explain why the student's circuit will not indicate any change in temperature above \(0^\circ \text{C}\)
The resistor of resistance \(5.0 \text{k}\Omega\) is changed to a resistor of resistance \(R\) so that the LED switches on or off at a temperature of \(20^{\circ}\text{C}\)
Determine \(R\) in \(\mathsf{k}\Omega\)
R =   .........  \(\mathsf{k}\Omega\)
The variation with temperature of the resistance of a thermistor is shown in Fig. 8.1
A student includes the thermistor and an ideal operational amplifier (op-amp) in the circuit of Fig. 8.2
State what is meant by a _magnetic field._
On Fig. 9.1, shade the face of the foil on which electrons initially accumulate
Explain why electrons do not continuously accumulate on the face you have shaded
A rectangular piece of aluminium foil is situated in a uniform magnetic field of flux density \(B\), as shown in Fig. 9.1
The magnetic field is normal to the face PQRS of the foil
Electrons, each of charge \(-q\), enter the foil at right angles to the face PQTv
State the meaning of the quantity \(n\)
Using the letters on Fig. 9.1, identify the distance \(t\)
The Hall voltage \(V_{\mathrm{H}}\) developed across the foil in **(b)** is given by the expression
where \(I\) is the current in the foil
Suggest why, in practice, Hall probes are usually made using a semiconductor material rather than a metal
State Lenz's law
A metal ring is suspended from a fixed point P by means of a thread, as shown in Fig. 10.1
The ring is displaced a distance \(d\) and then released. The ring completes many oscillations before coming to rest
The poles of a magnet are now placed near to the ring so that the ring hangs midway between the poles of the magnet, as shown in Fig. 10.2
The ring is again displaced a distance \(d\) and then released
Explain why the ring completes fewer oscillations before coming to rest
The ring in **(b)** is now cut so that it has the shape shown in Fig. 10.3
Explain why, when the procedure in **(b)** is repeated, the cut ring completes more oscillations than the complete ring when oscillating between the poles of the magnet
State how, in a modern X-ray tube, the intensity of the X-ray beam and its hardness are controlled
intensity:
hardness:
A parallel beam of X-rays of intensity \(I_0\) is incident normally on the model
Calculate, in terms of \(I_{\mathrm{0}}\) :
the transmitted intensity \(I_{\mathrm{S}}\) through soft tissue alone
the transmitted intensity \(I_{\mathrm{C}}\) through soft tissue and bone
A model of a limb consists of soft tissue and bone, as illustrated in Fig. 11.1
The soft tissue has a thickness of \(9.0 \text{cm}\). The bone within the soft tissue has a thickness of \(3.0 \text{cm}\)
Data for the linear attenuation (absorption) coefficient \(\mu\) of X-rays in soft tissue and in bone are shown in Table 11.1
By reference to your answers in **(b)**, suggest, with a reason, whether good contrast on an X-ray image would be obtained
Electromagnetic radiation of a single constant frequency is incident on a metal surface. This causes an electron to be emitted
Explain why the maximum kinetic energy of the electron is independent of the intensity of the incident radiation
the energy of a photon of the ultraviolet radiation
energy =   .........  eV
the work function energy of the surface of the zinc
energy =   .........  eV
Ultraviolet radiation of wavelength \(250\mathrm{nm}\) is incident on the surface of a sheet of zinc. The maximum kinetic energy of the emitted electrons is \(1.4\mathrm{eV}\)
Determine, in eV:
